discussion_comments.comment_body: Some of these look redundant. Don't we always have libc on linux?

If I remove libc dependency here, I get a compile failure.

```bash
$ cargo hack check -p tokio --all --feature-powerset --depth 2

...

info: running `cargo check --no-default-features --features fs,rt` on tokio (35/217)
    Checking tokio v1.45.0 (/home/mox692/work/tokio/tokio)
error[E0433]: failed to resolve: use of unresolved module or unlinked crate `libc`
  --> tokio/src/runtime/io/driver/uring.rs:67:56
   |
67 |                 Err(ref e) if e.raw_os_error() == Some(libc::EBUSY) => {
   |                                                        ^^^^ use of unresolved module or unlinked crate `libc`
   |
   = help: if you wanted to use a crate named `libc`, use `cargo add libc` to add it to your `Cargo.toml`
```

I suspect cargo doesn't always use libc even on unix (for example if we don't use signal, net, and process) since it's specified as [a optional dependency](https://github.com/tokio-rs/tokio/blob/ea30a5ea5eee1b3970052f19e8a8b16d0a5c29f4/tokio/Cargo.toml#L112).
Hmm. I'll have to think about what implications this has for our MSRV.

hashbrown 0.14.0 has a `rust-version = "1.64.0"`.
hashbrown 0.15.2 has a `rust-version = "1.65.0"`.

It doesn't seem to have an explicit MSRV policy, but it is inline with tokio-util's 1.70.0
I'm okay with this, but I don't want to require hashbrown if you're just using the `TaskTracker`. Can you add a `join_map` feature?
